repnme.cdata!: South Sudan - Water Supply and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Supply and
            Sanitation (WSS) Project for South Sudan were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was substantial; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: political and technical
            considerations must be closely managed during project design
            and implementation, and expectations on what a project can
            realistically deliver clearly accessed and communicated to
            all stakeholder constituencies' right from the outset.
            Project design in fragile and post conflict States, which
            often face multiple barriers to service delivery, including
            a capacity conundrum characterized by weak institutional
            structures and other limitations to the enabling
            environment, should be simple and flexible. Projects in
            fragile and post-conflict environments are sometimes
            developed and appraised with limited or incomplete
            information, and other dynamic conditions, which may create
            risks to implementation and outcomes. Trade-offs between
            quality and timeliness of delivering services should be
            carefully balanced, and project design should be cognizant
            of the fact that sustainable WSS service delivery requires
            adequate time to do well, especially in regard to the need
            for strengthening institutional capacity at the national,
            state, community, and civil society levels, and elements
            that require behavioral change such as CLTS. All aspects of
            procurement planning, including selection of procurement
            methods, contract packaging, and timing allowed for
            implementation of activities, and other pertinent factors in
            fragile and post-conflict situations such as South Sudan
            should be more flexible, duly considering the context in
            which operations are implemented.

repnme.cdata!:
South Sudan - Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project is to increase access to safe water
            supply and sanitation in all states by building a
            sustainable management system and developing the knowledge
            on water resources in Southern Sudan. This paper a level one
            restructuring of the project based on the findings and
            agreements reached between the Bank and the project
            stakeholders of the Republic of South Sudan (RSS) at a Mid
            Term Review (MTR) conducted during October 17-21, 2011. The
            restructuring is necessary to extend the project closing
            date by six months to December 31, 2012, to allow for
            completion of project activities and to rationalize the
            project development objective (PDO), development outcomes
            and outputs that are achievable by the new closing date. The
            restructuring thus includes: (i) revision of the PDO; (ii)
            deletion of one of the project outcome/result indicators in
            line with the proposed revision of the PDO; (iii) reduction
            in outcome targets; (iv) alignment of project costs in line
            with the reduced outputs, (v) reallocation of project funds;
            and (vi) extending the project closing date by six months to
            December 31, 2012.

14829749.trustfund:
TF096197-South Sudan Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Water Supply and Sanitation Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project is to increase access to safe water
            supply and sanitation in all states by building a
            sustainable management system and developing the knowledge
            on water resources in Southern Sudan. Based on the revised
            procurement plan, the project management team is actively
            processing the various activities identified in the plan.
            The closing date of the project was June 30, 2011. However
            the implementation of the project faced delays due to number
            of factors of which the major ones are: a) delays in signing
            and mobilization of the technical assistance for the project
            management team; b) the prevailing conditions in the country
            in relation to preparation for and carrying out of the
            national referendum which took place in January, 2011; and
            c) the rebidding of the major work contracts that was
            necessitated following a necessary repackaging to attract
            more competition from contractors. The Multi-Donor Trust
            Fund for Southern Sudan which was originally going too
            closed on June 30, 2011, has now been extended by the
            oversight committee to June 30, 2012.
